1.text: How beautiful art thou, my love, how beautiful art thou! thy eyes are dovesâ€™ eyes, besides what is hid within. Thy hair is as flocks of goats, which Come up from mount Galaad.

2.text: Thy teeth as flocks of sheep, that are shorn which come up from the washing, all with twins, and there is none barren among them.

3.text: Thy lips are as a scarlet lace: and thy speech sweet. Thy cheeks are as a piece of a pomegranate, besides that which lieth hid within.

4.text: Thy neck, is as the tower of David, which is built with bulwarks: a thousand bucklers hang upon it, all the armour of valiant men.

5.text: Thy two breasts like two young roes that are twins, which feed among the lilies.

6.text: Till the day break, and the shadows retire, I will go to the mountain of myrrh, and to the hill of frankincense.

7.text: Thou art all fair, O my love, and there is not a spot in thee.

8.text: Come from Libanus, my spouse, come from Libanus, come: thou shalt be crowned from the top of Amana, from the top of Sanir and Hermon, from the dens of the lions, from the mountains of the leopards.

9.text: Thou hast wounded my heart, my sister, my spouse, thou hast wounded my heart with one of thy eyes, and with one hair of thy neck.

10.text: How beautiful are thy breasts, my sister, my spouse! thy breasts are more beautiful than wine, and the sweet smell of thy ointments above all aromatical spices.

11.text: Thy lips, my spouse, are as a dropping honeycomb, honey and milk are under thy tongue; and the smell of thy garments, as the smell of frankincense.

12.text: My sister, my spouse, is a garden enclosed, a garden enclosed, a fountain sealed up.

13.text: Thy plants are a paradise of pomegranates with the fruits of the orchard. Cypress with spikenard.

14.text: Spikenard and saffron, sweet cane and cinnamon, with all the trees of Libanus, myrrh and aloes with all the chief perfumes.

15.text: The fountain of gardens: the well of living waters, which run with a strong stream from Libanus.

16.text: Arise, O north wind, and come, O south wind, blow through my garden, and let the aromatical spices thereof flow.
